report_title: Gas Stations with Convenience Stores in the US
executive_summary: Over the past five years, the Gas Stations with Convenience Stores industry has faced significant challenges because of fluctuating fuel prices, substantially influenced by global events like the COVID-19 pandemic, supply chain disruptions and geopolitical unrest. These fluctuations led to challenges in striking a balance between maximizing profit and maintaining competitive retail prices. Also, growing consumer inclination toward fuel-efficient and electric vehicles has begun to influence industry dynamics, posing a threat to retail gasoline sales. However, the industry showed resilience by shifting its focus to a more stable and predictable revenue source of convenience store sales. Industry operators expanded their product lines, spurred by an increase in overall consumer spending. Many gas stations transitioned from mere fuel stops to comprehensive service.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Volatile Fuel Prices Caused Revenue to Fluctuate
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Over the past five years, the Gas Stations with Convenience Stores industry has experienced instances of volatility because of fluctuating fuel prices, impacting the industry's revenue. COVID-19, supply chain disruptions and the Russian invasion of Ukraine all contributed to volatility in oil prices during the period.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Consumer Behavior Has Continued to Trend Toward Fuel-Efficient Cars
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Despite volatile trends in the world price of crude oil, per capita disposable income has grown, enabling consumers to upgrade to higher fuel grades and make more purchases on goods sold inside industry convenience stores. However, sales of eco-friendly cars, such as hybrids and electric vehicles, have been rising as more consumers invested in these vehicles to save on fuel costs as gasoline prices continued to inch up.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Profit Trends Have Seesawed, Mirroring Revenue Volatility
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Declines in the world price of crude oil in 2019 and 2020 led to an increase in profitability. When crude oil prices decline, establishments are better able to pass on some cost savings to consumers while still expanding margins. Consequently, the decline in the world price of crude oil led companies' profit to increase.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Expanding Non-Fuel Offerings Has Supported Revenue Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Over the past five years, there has been an upturn in overall consumer spending, this has fed into the growth of the Gas Stations with Convenience Stores industry as consumers have more disposable income to allocate towards non-essential goods and services offered at these locations. Convenience stores have responded by expanding their product lines to include a wider range of food and drink items, health and beauty products and general merchandise, boosting revenue.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Falling Oil Prices Will Pressure Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: In the next five years, a significant challenge for the industry will be the fall in oil prices. Oil prices are subject to numerous geopolitical and economic factors and prolonged periods of low oil prices can have a negative impact on the Gas Stations with Convenience Stores industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Increasing Health Consciousness Among Consumers Brings Challenges and Opportunities
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The growing health and wellness trend will significantly impact the Gas Stations with Convenience Stores industry over the next five years. As consumers become more health-conscious, demand for traditional convenience store offerings like salty snacks, sugary drinks and processed foods will drop.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Ownership of Retail Outlets Will Reshuffle
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Recent divestment activity demonstrates a long-term trend among large establishments of focusing more on the profitable oil discovery and production business segments. Oil companies will accelerate gas station divestiture to focus on profitable regions where they have the strongest brand recognition and, in turn, earn greater profit.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: A CONTINUED SHIFT TOWARDS ECO-FRIENDLY CARS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the next five years, the increasing consumer shift towards eco-friendly or alternative energy vehicles, especially electric and hydrogen-powered cars, will temper growth in the Gas Stations with Convenience Stores industry. This trend is majorly influenced by increasing environmental consciousness among consumers and aggressive environmental policies being adopted globally to combat climate change.

industry_definition: Industry operators sell automotive fuels such as gasoline and diesel from stations that are collocated with convenience stores or food marts. They may also provide automotive repair services. This industry is distinct from the Convenience Stores (IBISWorld report 44512) Gas Stations (44719) industries.

positive_impact_factors: high - steady Barriers To Entry Level

key_trends: Gas stations compete heavily on price. Fuel is a homogenous product, so downstream consumers typically seek out the lowest prices, especially when oil prices soar globally.

Snack sales have proven to be a popular addition to traditional gas stations, enabling establishments to generate additional revenue. As a result, more gas stations have added convenience stores to their operations, stiffening competition.
Volatile oil prices over the past five years have significantly impacted the industry. Prices have been extremely volatile because of COVID-19, supply chain disruptions and geopolitical tensions.
More gas stations have added convenience stores to bolster profitability, which fluctuates alongside oil prices. This has contributed to the expansion of the industry.
ACT is the largest company and is actively growing. The company acquired The Pantry in 2015 and CST in 2017 to increase its market share.

Although some companies have national coverage, many smaller companies cover a specific geographic region. Concentration has decreased over the past decade as more prominent companies in the industry divested gas stations.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This segment includes consumers under age 25. Because of minimum driver's licensing age requirements in each state, most drivers do not obtain their learner's permit until about the age of 15.
This market segment includes consumers aged between 25 and 34. While this demographic has largely entered the workforce, their average disposable incomes are less than older demographics.
This market segment includes individuals aged between 35 and 54 years old. This demographic visits gas stations with convenience stores most frequently.

This market segment includes consumers aged between 55 and 64 years old. These consumers experience higher disposable income levels such as their middle-aged counterparts and are more likely to pay for mid-grade and premium gasoline.

This market segment includes consumers aged 65 and older. This demographic tends to drive less frequently than younger consumers, as many of them are retired and only drive to run errands and participate in discretionary activities.

tier_1_suppliers: Oil Pipeline Transportation in the US
Oil Drilling & Gas Extraction in the US
Tank & Refrigeration Trucking in the US
Gasoline & Petroleum Wholesaling in the US
Employment & Recruiting Agencies in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The world price of crude oil significantly impacts the Gas Stations with Convenience Stores industry as crude oil is the primary raw material for fuel.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region has the highest percentage of establishments at 30% while its population percentage is 21%.
The Great Lakes region has 22% establishments but only 15% population.
The Southwest has 13% establishments compared to 11% population.
The West region has a lower percentage of establishments compared to its population percentage.
The Mid-Atlantic region has a lower percentage of establishments compared to its population percentage.
The Plains region has a higher percentage of establishments compared to its population percentage.
The New England region has an equal percentage of establishments and population.
The Rocky Mountains region has a higher percentage of establishments compared to its population percentage.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Petroleum Marketing Practices Act (PMPA) impacts gas stations with convenience stores by setting federal guidelines for the relationships between petroleum suppliers and gas station operators. It prevents unfair termination or non-renewal of franchise agreements, ensuring operators have adequate notice and reasons for such actions. This act protects gas station owners from abrupt business disruptions and promotes fair trading practices within the industry.

The Clean Air Act impacts gas stations with convenience stores by imposing regulations to control air pollution from fuel emissions. This includes requirements for vapor recovery systems and leak detection in underground storage tanks. Compliance ensures that harmful emissions are minimized, protecting public health and the environment. Meeting these standards can be costly and require continuous monitoring and maintenance.

For gas stations with convenience stores that sell food, adherence to food safety regulations is crucial. These rules, enforced by agencies like the FDA and local health departments, involve proper food handling, storage and hygiene standards to prevent contamination and ensure consumer safety. Compliance requires regular inspections and maintaining high standards, impacting operational practices and training.

Selling alcohol and tobacco products involves strict regulations, including obtaining special licenses, adhering to age verification laws and limiting sales hours. These rules aim to prevent underage sales and promote public health. Compliance ensures legal operation and avoids heavy fines, but it necessitates rigorous employee training and strict adherence to sales protocols.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Zoning Laws and Land Use Regulations
regulations_points.regulation_description: Local governments enforce zoning laws that dictate where gas stations can be built and operated. These regulations also cover issues like signage, traffic impact and proximity to residential areas. Compliance ensures that gas stations are situated appropriately to minimize disruptions to the community.

The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) sets regulations to ensure employee safety at gas stations with convenience stores. This includes guidelines on handling hazardous materials, proper signage for safety, and routine training for staff. Complying with OSHA standards helps prevent workplace accidents and injuries, creating a safer environment for employees and customers.

Gas stations with convenience stores must obtain various licenses to operate, including business licenses, fuel dispenser permits and food sales permits for their convenience stores. State and local governments enforce these licensing requirements, which vary by location. Meeting these regulations ensures legal operation and avoids penalties, but navigating the bureaucratic process can be time-consuming and complex.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The gas station with convenience store industry is mature.
The industry receives low and steady levels of assistance.
There is high and steady competition in the industry.
Stringent zoning laws and environmental regulations create significant legal barriers for new entrants.
Large upfront capital investment is needed to obtain a station site, fuel, and inventory.
Standing out is challenging in a saturated market with established brands.
While labor requirements are limited, employees are still a necessity making labor expenses significant.

factors_decreased_barrier: The industry has a low concentration level.
There is a low level of technology change.
The industry has a low and decreasing level of globalization.

basis_points.basis_description: Gas stations compete heavily on price as fuel is a homogenous product.
Snack and convenience item sales have become an important revenue stream.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry is essentially a local business with stations spread geographically, making it difficult for a single operator to dominate.
Larger companies can benefit from economies of scale in areas like fuel purchasing, marketing, and supply chain.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: The Cost of Fuel Drives Purchase Cost Trends
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: While fuel accounts for the majority of purchases, companies also buy convenience store items such as cigarettes, foodstuffs and beverages for resale.

Fuel prices significantly impact industry profit. When crude oil prices rise, the cost of fuel supplies for gas stations rises. While stations can pass these costs onto consumers by raising fuel prices, higher prices can also lead to a reduction in fuel consumption, impacting profit.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Necessary Labor Keeps Wage Costs High
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Many gas stations operate 24 hours a day, 365 days a year, requiring multiple shifts of workers, which increases wage costs. Employees must be trained in the operation of specialized equipment and health and safety protocols, contributing to high wage costs. The industry often experiences high employee turnover, which leads to recurring recruitment and training costs.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Labor requirements are limited, as gas stations with convenience stores primarily employ part-time workers that demand low wages. However, employees are still a necessity, which makes labor expenses significant.

volatility_points.volatility_title: CRUDE OIL PRICES DRIVE REVENUE VOLATILITY
volatility_points.volatility_description: Gas prices are highly sensitive to global oil market fluctuations, which can lead to sudden price changes at the pump, affecting consumer behavior and sales volume.

Offering both fuel and convenience store items helps industry operators diversify their revenue streams, somewhat limiting volatility. While fuel sales can fluctuate with volatile oil prices and changing driving habits, convenience store sales can provide a more stable income.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: BIOFUEL GIVES NEW LIFE TO PETROLEUM PRODUCTS
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: While biofuels alone are considered a substitute for petroleum products, many wholesalers sell blended petroleum and biofuel products. This innovation caters to the growing consumer demand for sustainable energy solutions. Not only do biofuels help reduce carbon emissions, but their integration also expands the product offering of gas stations, giving them a competitive edge.

Gas stations incorporating EV charging stations cater to the growing electric vehicle market, attracting a new customer segment. EV charging takes longer than traditional fueling, increasing the time customers spend in the convenience store, which boosts in-store sales.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or do you retail a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Store owners have begun to focus more on their convenience store businesses, because of the higher profitability of store items than gasoline, by offering various goods inside their stores, including prepackaged meals and healthier snack options.

FAQs.question: Are your customers heavily price-conscious?
FAQs.answer: Price and location largely determine where consumers purchase gasoline and convenience store items.

FAQs.question: Have declining input costs negatively affected your company's sales?
FAQs.answer: When the world price of crude oil declines, revenue declines while profit margins swell.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities in order to expand reach and reduce overhead expenses?
FAQs.answer: The industry's largest stores have invested heavily in merger and acquisition activity to achieve economies of scale.

FAQs.question: How does your company utilize new payment technology in its operations?
FAQs.answer: Several stores have experimented with new payment technologies like finger scanners and wireless devices, to boost efficiency.

FAQs.question: Does your company use point-of-sale (POS) systems to ensure that the most popular products are kept in stock?
FAQs.answer: Convenience stores implement point-of-sale systems to boost profit margins by keeping up demand for popular items.

FAQs.question: What does your company do to remain compliant with new regulations?
FAQs.answer: Gas stations with convenience stores endure a high level of regulation, mostly because of gasoline quality and handling standards.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: The National Association of Convenience Stores lobbies on behalf of the industry on issues related to credit card fees, motor fuels, tobacco and labor.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Profit margin remains narrow because of elevated fuel costs. Gas stations have focused more on increasing the sale of non-fuel items due to the higher profit that they earn when compared with gasoline.

FAQs.question: How have volatile input prices affected profit margins?
FAQs.answer: Profitability depends on oil prices. Lower oil prices can weaken revenue while bolstering profitability, while rising oil prices does the opposite.

FAQs.question: Is your company dominant in any particular regional markets? What range does your company have in terms of viable operating area?
FAQs.answer: Gas stations with department stores that are located near high traffic areas provide ease of access to customers. Locations should also be remote from other gas stations.

FAQs.question: Do you have a good reputation for excellent customer service? Do you differentiate your product offerings?
FAQs.answer: Gas stations that offer a range of products and services attract and retain more customers. Also, convenience store products are more profitable than gasoline, making it beneficial to focus on the convenience business.

FAQs.question: How do you keep track of the company's expenditures? What costs can you cut back on? Are there any systems you can use to effectively control costs?
FAQs.answer: Administrative skills like financial and debt management are particularly important when input costs climb.

FAQs.question: Have you monitored the influence of gas prices on your business?
FAQs.answer: When crude oil prices rise, stores absorb more of these costs than they are able to pass on, because of the high level of competition within the industry. Revenue jumps in periods of crude oil price growth, but profit drops.

FAQs.question: How will your company adapt to changes in total miles driven by vehicles?
FAQs.answer: More miles traveled by car means consumers need gas leading to higher retail sales of transport fuels. More fuel sales contribute directly to industry revenue.

FAQs.question: Consumer spending
FAQs.answer: As consumer spending grows, consumers are more inclined to trade up to premium fuel grades. Spending on convenience store items, like food and drinks, expands, bolstering revenue.
